MR. Dr. SAMUEL CLARK, in his 'demon≈øtration of the being and attributes of GOD,' undertakes to prove, that he 'exi≈øts by a nece≈ø≈øity ab≈øolute in the nature of the thing it≈øelf'‚Äî'a nece≈ø≈øity antecedent. The Dr. takes his ri≈øe to the nece≈ø≈øity of the divine exi≈øtence from hence, That 'there hath exi≈øted from eternity ≈øome one independent being, the author of all other beings.' (vid. p. 8,‚Äî15. WHY then did the Dr. lay down his two fir≈øt propo≈øitions (p. 8, 11.) as the media of proof? div.head: SECT. I. Whether the will be nece≈ø≈øarily determined by an extrin≈øic cau≈øe?
div.p:
MR. Edwards would have his readers 'ob≈øerve, that when he ≈øpeaks of connection of cau≈øes and effects, he hath re≈øpect to moral cau≈øes, as well as tho≈øe that are called natural in di≈øtinction from them‚Äîthat the acts of the will may be as certainly and indi≈ø≈øolubly connected with the moral cau≈øe, as natural effects with their natural cau≈øes‚Äîthat the connection is as ≈øure and perfect between moral cau≈øes and effects, as natural; that moral nece≈ø≈øity may be as ab≈øolute as natural nece≈ø≈øity.'Part I. INDEED, if there be not a real and important di≈øtinction between moral cau≈øes and natural, it plainly follows, that Mr. Edwards hath taken pains to no purpo≈øe to ≈øhew, that natural nece≈ø≈øity wholly precludes from prai≈øe or blame, while moral nece≈ø≈øity doth not at all. IN the ≈øection la≈øt referred to, Mr. Edwards ≈øugge≈øts, that 'when we ≈øpeak of choice as di≈øtinct from nature, it is without reflection and re≈øearch; names being given to things according to what is mo≈øt obvious. The difference is important, but not ≈øen≈øible and obvious. But are we not told in this ≈øame place, that the effect is al≈øo connected with the natural cau≈øe, and is owing to the nature of things? IT is difficult to determine whether Mr. Edwards ≈øuppo≈øed the acts of the will to be the nece≈ø≈øary effects of an intrin≈øic cau≈øe, or an extrin≈øic. Either
internal, original bias, or ≈øomething extrin≈øic, is the cau≈øe, to who≈øe efficiency, determination, command, deci≈øion, the will is as much ≈øubject, as the motion of the body to the will‚Äîthis being 'as pa≈ø≈øive and nece≈ø≈øary with re≈øpect to the antecedent determining cau≈øe of it,' as the motions of the hands and feet with re≈øpect to the determination of the will. (183, 184)

WE rather think it was Mr. Edwards's opinion, that the will is determined by an extrin≈øic cau≈øe. But ≈øince this is by no means certain from his book‚Äî≈øince he hath not expre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf clearly, or we are incapable judges of this intricate ≈øubject, we ≈øhall take liberty to examine his doctrine on both ≈øuppo≈øitions‚Äîeither of an extrin≈øic, or intrin≈øic cau≈øe. WHETHER volition is nece≈ø≈øarily determined by an extrin≈øic cau≈øe? Mr. Edwards a≈ø≈øerts, that the acts of the will are not nece≈ø≈øary in them≈øelves, or in their own nature; but by their connection with ≈øome cau≈øe that is nece≈ø≈øary in it≈øelf. div.head: SECT. III. Upon Mr. Edwards's own Scheme, there cannot be natural Liberty without moral.
div.p: WE acknowledge the title of this ≈øection contains a po≈øition directly repugnant to Mr. Edwards's whole ≈øcheme, and yet tru≈øt we ≈øhall make it appear that the thing a≈ø≈øerted plainly follows from things he hath advanced.

LIBERTY with re≈øpect to natural actions can be neither more nor le≈øs than according to the freedom of the will, or mind. Now 'there cannot be more in the effect than in the cau≈øe. Tho≈øe things which are indi≈ø≈øolubly connected with other things that are nece≈ø≈øary, are them≈øelves nece≈ø≈øary.' (286.) The acts of the ≈øoul or will being, therefore, nece≈ø≈øary effects of ≈øome other cau≈øe than the agent, let it be ≈øhewn how there can be ≈øo much as natural liberty‚Äîmeaning hereby a freedom from outward con≈øtraint or re≈øtraint.

MR. Edwards a≈ø≈øerts, 'The liberty of the will is not exerci≈øed in any thing but what the will does'. (99.) 'The will in no in≈øtance whatever is it's own determiner'. Therefore the liberty of the will is not exerci≈øed in any of the determinations of the will. Therefore not in determining to move the body. Therefore corporeal action is not voluntary. Therefore the will does nothing. Therefore it is exerci≈øed in nothing. Mr. Edwards promi≈øeth to 'demon≈øtrate', that 'if the fir≈øt act in the train, determining and fixing the re≈øt, be not free, none of them all are free.' In one word, external action is no more in our power than internal. To ≈øay that the will determines the former is not true: For this would be to ≈øuppo≈øe it is its own determiner at lea≈øt in this particular determination to move the body; contrary to a≈ø≈øertion, that it is in no in≈øtance whatever it's own determiner. But ≈øuppo≈øe material actions to be determined by the will, that herein men are the voluntary cau≈øes of their own actions‚Äîthis is really attributing no power to the will or agent‚Äî≈øince all the acts of the will ≈øuppo≈øe an an≈øwerable
cau≈øe without, as much as creation ≈øuppo≈øeth a creator. (62.)

If material actions are ≈øubject to, and commanded by, the will, ≈øtill this is ≈øubject to and determined by preceeding nece≈ø≈øity. So that natural liberty is given up. For that is a ≈øtrange kind of liberty, which is founded in, and re≈øults out of, nece≈ø≈øity. Whether this nece≈ø≈øity be natural or moral‚Äîwhether it proceeds from an extrin≈øic or intrin≈øic cau≈øe, it equally militates again≈øt the ≈øuppo≈øition of freedom. Page 232 (and el≈øewhere) Mr. Edwards hath an eva≈øion, which ≈øcarce de≈øerves a ≈øerious an≈øwer It is this, 'that a man may be ≈øaid to have a thing in his power, if he has it at his election; i. e. if he now plea≈øeth, and has a direct and immediate de≈øire for it, he is not unable to do it.' This, in mo≈øt writers, would be e≈øteemed meer quibbling. For if a man is morally incapable of a 'direct and immediate de≈øire' to a thing, how can he be ≈øaid to have it in his power? Would Mr. Edwards ≈øay, that things are in or out of men's power, farther than chu≈øing or refu≈øing is ≈øo, as well as the con≈øequent acts depending hereon? It is not improper to ≈øay, 'that a per≈øon' cannot 'perform tho≈øe actions, which depend on an act of will, when the act of will it≈øelf cannot be pre≈øent,' but is forever impo≈ø≈øible'‚Äîwhen the di≈øpo≈øition to the contrary is 'as ≈øtrong and immoveable as the bars of a ca≈øtle,' by nature‚Äîwhen want of inclination proceeds from nature; or original bias. For 'the event is dependent on it's cau≈øe.' And the cau≈øe not being put, the event cannot take place. Admitting that ≈øuch a ≈øtate of the will may be

In this Mr. Edwards con≈øtantly a≈ø≈øerts a man has not power, or liberty of choice, while he grants him a power or capacity of con≈øequent choice. UPON the whole: Mr. Edwards allows, that liberty is e≈ø≈øential to prai≈øe or blame, reward or puni≈øhment; but teacheth, that the internal ≈øtate of the mind or will proceeds not from, is not determined by, our≈øelves. Quaere, Whether Mr. Edwards's motto at all favors this opinion? It is taken from Rom. ix.xvi. It is not of him that willeth. I≈øaac did really will to give the ble≈ø≈øing to E≈øau‚ÄîE≈øau did run for veni≈øon to obtain it. But the will of the one, and the running of the other, were over-ruled. div.head: SECT. IV. Of GOD's being the Author of Sin, upon Mr. Edwards's Scheme of nece≈ø≈øity; and in what Sen≈øe he admits this to be the Con≈øequence of his Doctrine.
div.p: MR Edwards teacheth, 'That GOD, when he had made man, ≈øo ordered his circum≈øtances, that from the≈øe circum≈øtances, together with the withholding divine influence and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, his ≈øin infallibly followed.' And when it is a≈øked hereupon, 'why might not GOD as well have fir≈øt made man with a fixed, prevailing principle of ≈øin in his heart?' Mr. Edwards intimates in his an≈øwer, that GOD might indeed have done ≈øo; but adds, that if man had been thus made at fir≈øt, 'it would not have been ≈øo vi≈øible, that ≈øin did not ari≈øe from GOD, as the po≈øitive cau≈øe, and real ≈øource of it‚Äîthat therefore it was meet man ≈øhould not be made with ≈øin in his heart, that ≈øin might appear to ari≈øe from the imperfection of the creature, 'and not from GOD as the efficient or fountain.' He allows GOD to be the author of ≈øin in any ≈øen≈øe but being 'the agent, or actor of ≈øin, or doer of the wicked thing.' He 'di≈øpo≈øeth the ≈øtate of events in ≈øuch a manner, that ≈øin mo≈øt certainly follows therefrom. In ≈øuch a ≈øen≈øe, I do not deny, that GOD is the author of ≈øin. (Part iv. ≈øect. 9, 10. and p. 402, 408.

Now how doth it appear, on the≈øe principles, that God is not the po≈øitive cau≈øe, and real ≈øource of moral evil? Every one perceives a difference between doing (or being the ≈øubject of) a wicked thing, and being the efficient cau≈øe and fountain of it‚ÄîMr. Edwards allows, that the moral turpitude lies wholly in the inward propen≈øity, and can no farther be applied to the corporeal action, than as a vicious principle is ≈øuppo≈øed to be the ≈øource of it. If then we have no power of ≈øelf-determination in relation to the internal acts and exerci≈øes of the mind‚Äîif the only thing wherein human liberty con≈øi≈øts, is, a power of executing what is already willed‚Äîif volition ≈øprings not from man as the ≈øource, cau≈øe, or efficient of it‚Äîif he is only the ≈øubject, the doer, the actor of ≈øin‚ÄîWho then is the po≈øitive cau≈øe and fountain of it? if not the creature, who but the creator? Every thing but the action or doing of wickedne≈øs, Mr. Edwards expre≈øly affirms GOD to be the author of, and ≈øaith it is no reproach to him. So that unle≈øs he would confound cau≈øe and effect‚Äîunle≈øs he would allow men to be 'the de≈øigning voluntary cau≈øe of their own volitions;' (which he con≈øtantly denies) there is no evading the con≈øequence, that GOD is the ≈øource and fountain, the po≈øitive cau≈øe and efficient, of moral evil‚Äîyea, Mr. Edwards ≈øaith, that he 'deci≈øively orders all the volitions of moral agents by a po≈øitive influence'‚Äî(40.) which is nothing le≈øs than ≈øaying in expre≈øs terms, that he is the po≈øitive cau≈øe and efficient of them.

Mr. Edwards's notion of human liberty, as being exerci≈øed and concerned in outward actions only, in contradi≈øtinction from an inward power of ≈øelf-determination (or activity in volition
‚Äîor liberty in the mind or will) if viewed in it's direct and immediate con≈øequences, we think mu≈øt appear to ≈øubvert the very foundation of religion and morality. This appears to be the plain con≈øequence by his own principles. For he very ju≈øtly ob≈øerves, that 'the e≈ø≈øence of all moral good or evil lies in the internal inclinations, di≈øpo≈øitions, volitions'‚Äîthat as the≈øe 'are the cau≈øe of outward actions, ≈øo the moral good or evil of ≈øuch actions doth not lie at all in the actions them≈øelves, which taken by them≈øelves are nothing of a moral nature; but in the internal inclinations and volitions which are the cau≈øe of them'‚Äî(276) that 'vice and virtue lie in the ≈øtate or frame of the ≈øoul, and in this only'‚Äîthat 'the very willing is the doing; when once a man has willed, the thing is performed, and nothing el≈øe remains to be done‚Äîthat the will it≈øelf is the proper object of commands, as well as tho≈øe actions which are the effects of the will. It is manife≈øt the ≈øoul only is properly and directly the ≈øubject of precepts or commands, that only being capable of receiving or perceiving them. The motions or ≈øtate of the body are matter of command only as they are ≈øubject to the ≈øoul, and connected with it's acts.' Part 3. Sect. 4. & 5. Now if inward freedom enters not into the notion of human liberty (33, 38, 39, 40, 131, 132, 189, 194, 213,‚Äî215, 234, 236, 256,‚Äî289, and pa≈ø≈øim.) then we are not free in that wherein lies the e≈ø≈øence of virtue and vice: And if we are not free in this re≈øpect e≈øpecially, how are we free in any ≈øen≈øe that is of the lea≈øt importance? how can we be virtuous or vicious, if liberty (as Mr. Edwards grants) is nece≈ø≈øary to moral good or evil? Yea, if we are not free with re≈øpect to the
thoughts, affections and purpo≈øes of our hearts, our inward inclinations and volitions, hath not Mr. Edwards ≈øhewn undeniably that we cannot be free in regard to outward actions? 'If there be a ≈øeries of acts, the determining act is more e≈øpecially the ≈øubject of command‚Äîbecau≈øe it is this act that determines the whole affair.' So that we are not at liberty in that which determines the whole character. Nothing can be more futile than the eva≈øion, that 'the e≈ø≈øence of virtue and vice lies in the nature of volition, not in the cau≈øe'‚Äîas if meer effects might be virtuous or vicious, and the cau≈øe that produceth them not ≈øo‚ÄîOr ≈øuppo≈øing the cau≈øe (of a ≈øinful volition, for in≈øtance) to be vicious, as if the pa≈ø≈øive effect would be another and di≈øtinct wickedne≈øs. Be≈øides, if the ≈øubject of ≈øuch a volition, who is altogether pa≈ø≈øive herein, is vicious notwith≈øtanding, then how is liberty nece≈ø≈øary to prai≈øe or blame? MOREOVER, outward actions being determined by the will, and partaking of the nature of moral good or evil only with reference to their cau≈øe, viz. internal volition‚Äîhow is this (internal volition) virtuous „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ in it's own nature, when the acts of the body are not? Why then are outward acts declared virtuous or vicious only with reference to their cau≈øe, while this is denied of volition? Hath every act of volition an antecedent, nece≈ø≈øary
cau≈øe, which determineth not only volition, but, of con≈øequence, outward actions? 'Thus' Mr. Edwards's 'notion of liberty, con≈øi≈øting' in external freedom, 'is repugnant to it≈øelf, and ≈øhuts it≈øelf wholly out of the world.'

WERE it indeed true, as Mr Edwards incidentally ob≈øerves, (contrary to the general doctrine of his book, and his whole ≈øcheme) that we 'have command over our thoughts'‚Äî(p. 894) that 'the acts of the will are free'‚Äîthat 'the ≈øoul has freedom'‚Äî(p. 116, 224) this might ≈øolve the difficulty, as it would be to make men the voluntary de≈øigning cau≈øe of tho≈øe inward acts wherein the nature of virtue and vice con≈øi≈øts. But, as before ob≈øerved, Mr. Edwards con≈øtantly denies an inward principle, ≈øource, or power of activity‚Äîand blames tho≈øe divines who contend for the freedom of the ≈øoul in willing. He allows, that a man hath 'power to move his body agreably to an antecedent act of choice, but not to u≈øe or exert the faculties of his ≈øoul.' (p. 131) How then 'hath the ≈øoul a power of volition or choice?' (p. 39) of chu≈øing for in≈øtance, to move the body, when it hath not a power of exerting its own faculties? How much more con≈øi≈øtent would it have been for Mr Edwards to have ≈øaid, that the will's determining is a nece≈ø≈øary determining‚Äî for the ≈øoul to act nece≈ø≈øarily is evermore to act nece≈ø≈øarily?‚Äî(that is, the will does not determine, the ≈øoul does not act) than to ≈øay, 'the will's determining is a free determining‚Äîfor the ≈øoul to act voluntarily is evermore to act electively'?
The will, the ≈øoul, may be acted upon, and have ≈øuch a volition or choice produced in it, in con≈øequence, and as the effect, of ≈øome cau≈øe operating on it, deciding and determining the volition. What Mr. Edwards calls the ≈øoul's voluntary, elective acts, are the effects of a cau≈øe independent on man. The acts and exerci≈øes of the human mind (if they may be called its acts) are owing not to any active power in the mind, to any thing within its power, but entirely to the energy of a nece≈ø≈øary cau≈øe, which is prior to what are called its own acts. Volition is free or voluntary with a freedom of moral nece≈ø≈øity‚Äî a nece≈ø≈øity as ab≈øolute as natural. And thus it is, that a man's heart comes to be wrong or right.

MR. Edwards teacheth, that GOD 'orders the volitions of moral agents, among other events, with ≈øuch a deci≈øive di≈øpo≈øal, that the events are infallibly connected with his di≈øpo≈øal‚Äîthat an univer≈øal, determining providence infers an infallible, previous fixedne≈øs of all events‚Äîthat GOD's own immediate conduct is fir≈øt in the ≈øeries, and this alone unconnected with any thing preceeding‚Äîthat he cau≈øeth the di≈øpo≈øition of the mind to be more in favour of ≈øuch acts'‚Äî(vicious no le≈øs than virtuous) 'or bringeth the mind more into view of powerful motives and inducements'‚Äîthat all things are invariably ≈øettled‚Äîand 'nece≈ø≈øity belongs to all moral agents.' His ≈øcheme, upon the whole, appears to be nearly the ≈øame with that exhibited by the celebrated Mr. Hume, an epicurean athei≈øt, which we ≈øhall give the reader in his own words. TO this ≈øcheme, Mr. Hume ≈øuppo≈øeth it will be objected in the following form. And we mu≈øt conclude, therefore, either that they are not criminal, or that the Deity, not man, is accountable for them. But as either of the≈øe po≈øitions is ab≈øurd

THIS objection, which Mr. Hume ≈øtates to him≈øelf, may be made with the ≈øame propriety to the general ≈øcheme of our author. Hume acknowledgeth, that upon his ≈øcheme, the Deity is the mediate, original cau≈øe or all the actions of men; and virtually admits the con≈øequence; (that he is therefore the author of ≈øin and moral turpitude) by ob≈øerving, that it is not po≈ø≈øible di≈øtinctly to explain, how he can be the one, and not the other. div.head: SECT. V. On the ≈øuppo≈øed Advantage of moral Evil to the Univer≈øe.
div.p: HAVING taken notice of Mr. Edwards's doctrine, in a≈ø≈øerting GOD to be the author of ≈øin, except that he is not 'the actor of it, or doer of the wicked thing; and the eva≈øion which ≈øuch a doctrine needed, that 'the e≈ø≈øence of a ≈øinful volition is in its nature, not in its cau≈øe'; the next advance he makes, in order to reconcile the exi≈øtence of ≈øin with the divine choice and determination, in the invariable nece≈ø≈øity or it, is, that moral evil is be≈øt for the world‚Äîthat therefore 'an infinitely wi≈øe being, who always chu≈øes what is be≈øt, mu≈øt chu≈øe there ≈øhould be ≈øuch a thing'‚Äîthat this is not chu≈øing what is properly evil upon the whole, becau≈øe 'of the great good which is the con≈øequence of ≈øin, for the ≈øake' of which GOD is ≈øuppo≈øed to 'will ≈øin.'
